repnme.cdata!:
Mauritius - Port Development and
            Environmental Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is highly satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; overall
            Bank performance is highly satisfactory; and overall
            Borrower performance is highly satisfactory. The following
            lessons may be drawn from the experience of this project: 1)
            Keyfactors for a successful infrastructure port reform
            project are strong commitment from government, consistency
            of political will even when administrations change, and an
            inclusive participatory approach with a broad consultation
            process. 2) A good monitoring indicator system can help a
            port operator to adapt both its operating strategy and
            productivity level quickly when it needs to respond to
            changes in market demand. 3) Once a port has proved to be
            commercially successful, private sector investment should be
            a strong option for any future development, since its
            viability will encourage potential investors to take on the
            risks involved. The participation of the private sector
            usually also ensures a speedier response to changing market conditions.

Mauritius - Port Development and

6539069.trustfund:
TF023047-PHRD-PORT EXTENSION AND
            FREEPORT POJECT,TF023410-SIDA CTF FOR ENVIRONMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritius - Port Development and
            Environment Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            satisfactory, with a highly likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts, and,
            similarly, ratings assess the Bank performance as
            satisfactory, and that of the Borrower as highly
            satisfactory. Lessons of success are attributed, first, to a
            consistent political will, government commitment, and strong
            ownership, irrespective of administration changes. Likewise,
            the participatory approach, and consultation process helped
            dilute social risks, during project preparation,
            negotiations, and implementation, especially with trade
            unions, and, in particular, the Master Plan Study
            participatory management, and appropriate Project Steering
            Committee complemented the nature of this project. The
            project is thus looked upon as a role model in the
            implementation of projects in Mauritius, a project which was
            instrumental in creating a new vision for port management,
            as well as for social aspects with the introduction of the
            Voluntary Retirement Scheme concept. Regardless of success,
            the exchange risk issue, faced by the Mauritius Ports
            Authority (MPA), exposed the limitations of the existing
            financial market arrangements, to a large extent, beyond
            MPA's control. This suggests the Government should
            consider other financial instruments, to provide
            institutional ability to hedge against foreign exchange
            risks; similarly, the Bank should consider introducing some
            mechanisms/formula to limit client's exposure on
            foreign exchange as a percentage of its revenue.

18225739.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Trade and integration

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritius - Port Development and
            Environment Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Mauritius
            Port Development and Environment Protection Project is to
            enhance Mauritius's transport and trade competitiveness
            in the maritime sector, in an environmentally sound manner.
            To this end, the project will help: 1) increase port
            productivity, efficiency and capacity to meet the demand of
            port users and operators at competitive rates through
            extension of facilities mechanization and improved
            management of the Mauritius Maritime Authority (MMA), Cargo
            Handling Corporation (CHC), and Mauritius Freeport Authority
            (MFA); 2) re-define the role of MMA as a landlord port
            authority working through a system of competitive concession
            contracts with performance indicators for port opertaions;
            3) support the development of MFA to promote Mauritius as an
            attractive tax-free base for regional entrepot trade; and 4)
            accompany port development with sound environmental
            protection, including control of maritime pollution, and
            port operations and vessels' safety enhancement.

docna.cdata!:
Mauritius - Port Development and Environment
            Protection Project
